29EEAFC426594A338D0B4FF6D901C1FF.description: Identify and use criteria to evaluate growth in one’s ability to establish supports for health.

0B8CDEE30F684138AB94BF0C28559E8A.description: Distinguish, with others, criteria to evaluate the implementation of “supporting others” action plans

AC5890FD9BA349258E736B981D93DB67.description: Identify criteria and use them to assess the design elements of “supporting others” action plans.

236A4FF9AC424030BA82981D631DBF8B.description: Plan the required steps to complete action plans that support others

A3E84CABC1844FDD827A64D74BBB39E2.description: Determine the elements of effective “support” action plans (e.g., who, what, where, when, how, why).

DF3C224D46AA4A27A2BB35E79A6AFB43.description: Design, implement, and evaluate three seven-day action plans that establish multiple supports for responsible health action related to family roles and responsibilities, non-curable infections/diseases, violence and abuse, body image, sustainability, and sexual health.

05F806F880E94103BD08EDCBE9B1F3EE.description: Apply decisions that will improve personal health and/or the health of others.

9B937B7342F64F64B32899548986555A.description: Establish multiple and authentic supports in planning for healthy decision making.

FF85C863E1994859A9059F8247D49FAB.description: Predict the consequences of such strategies.

367DAA60024940EAB572EEA21E629582.description: Determine strategies for meeting individual “support” goals.

36F24BBA0E9A425D85153318926AEB1B.description: Design a personal goal statement that supports others in each unit of study.

D362F7D33E5C48259902B6A40BE378C5.description: Examine factors that affect the support one may give or receive.

194484CC34B4428A81505B6EFAD48E2D.description: Discuss and evaluate various alternatives to address health opportunities/challenges.

C49A9E099BBD44728BD57D0400279AA3.description: Examine possible health opportunities and health challenges related to each unit of study.

408AB5BD07264D7B939015DC25F5993C.description: Assess current skills and abilities to be a support person.

09BFB45150CF4E83BE04670E9DF0AFC8.description: Analyze the health opportunities and challenges, and establish “support others” personal goal statements, related to family roles and responsibilities, non-curable infections/diseases, violence and abuse, body image, sustainability, and sexual health.

289D7B1ADE7244C3B80D1DC7BA8F748C.description: Describe the influencing factors on providing and receiving support.

14DEFC0CBC0741CF86A52F39327204D8.description: Recognize the kinds of support that may be needed at various stages/steps when making decisions.

74087686F52440AB9B0CA48EC82E8E0D.description: Examine the implications or consequences of support strategies.

15E7B78E3526423CB5CDBBF2417E289D.description: Distinguish between wanting and needing support.

187C146E2D9D4D3A89FA7BD8470609C5.description: Discuss ways to determine when support is needed.

A26F29450B60454EA9CD93E62A677EC9.description: Critique the various kinds of support.

9AA746D735D04AE592CC34246AE67013.description: Review the kinds of support that one may need when making healthy decisions

0287C632CA1C4991A6E2D9457E5E0FE3.description: Appraise the role of “support” in making healthy decisions related to family roles and responsibilities, non-curable infections/ diseases, violence and abuse, body image, sustainability, and sexual health.

47DAB3E53BA94C9BADA2AE59030EF36A.description: Make informed decisions based on health-related knowledge.

47A68B63E6374EAC8A69810886FEAFF8.description: Determine how access to sexual health supports and services influence personal and community sexual health.

F4D0327A4102413D85E38050CC9EE7B7.description: Analyze sexual health supports and services in the community.

3A76C0E919BD4FDAB8FB8538FC0AFBE6.description: Analyze ways to support others and their dignity in decisions related to sexual health.

699C0B23E3E045ACA04AE90891756101.description: Appraise the strategies of personal commitment (see grade 7) that are required to commit to one’s standards and to respond to the social, cultural, and environmental influences.

9DF2CF6B303A4D43802A36EE06E1DA2D.description: Examine and develop an understanding of influences on responsible sexual health decisions (e.g., family, culture, social, religion).

EB80D889A8BD4EAD90CAC3187345FF69.description: Examine how the social, cultural, and environmental influences may determine people’s knowledge and access to sexual health information.

ADF71754AB5F4B9BBD31498C8D24C93C.description: Determine the possible consequences of not knowing and questioning community attitudes/norms

1AC935D57EE343CA9E4409EF6582E0F3.description: Compare sexual attitudes/norms of adults to those of youth in the community.

F96A7BC7D5DD42008570E91814D5F4DF.description: Examine influences that shape community norms about sexual health.

2C11E5BABD5C4753A00C2D1BDD49340E.description: Locate and evaluate, according to student-generated criteria, both sources of and information about sexual health.

1410051307B240CC855D54FE1560D0C5.description: Compare the perceived and actual sexual attitudes/norms in the community.

04E582124B9049F29DBBB5EA8087C45B.description: Assess the social, cultural, and environmental influences on and supports for sexual health knowledge, attitudes, behaviours, and decisions.

FDC75079E28A42509B16A52DF9D8B544.description: Discuss contributions of traditional First Nations and Métis people to environmental health.

A3A6D478205C48ED8082FC59B1807F43.description: Investigate social action groups/networks that exist to protect the environment and to support people in achieving optimal health.

9657E41D62804610925DCB5BCF03A070.description: Investigate past and present practices that focus/focused on sustainability for the health of people and the environment.

BEAA5B4178B04B289AB5D1F66650F07B.description: Evaluate three or more examples of perceptions on what is believed to be healthy/sustainable for the environment (i.e., examine local and provincial perspectives)

E3B9E3D7D3D04620B1A269827E825A06.description: Consider the kinds of changes needed to protect the environment and the health of people.

B748E24015F14820A7AF6F7C33ED4087.description: Analyze how one’s behaviour related to the concept of sustainability, might affect the well-being of others and other things

D4291506F9AD453AA2C2A3C7F15CFBA6.description: Analyze rules, regulations, and laws related to environmental health and the health of individuals.

A1CA363E0A614189BCE2175BDDA74110.description: Question family and community norms and expectations regarding caring for the environment.

6BB42F26250541A3A550341F4BAC5026.description: Examine practices and activities that pose a threat to the environment and to the health of people.

D4E42AD2837F478C86FC0704B9DD8F6A.description: Examine and appreciate the ways natural environments meet physical, aesthetic, and spiritual needs.

38A94231EE6045B9BE66095FDC5EE29A.description: Investigate the connections between the health of the environment and the health of people.

9D2E8D88E2194DD999CB7781EE3FA06D.description: Locate and evaluate, according to student-generated criteria, both sources of and information about sustainability.

1500D65AA3C04463B29065E0540E9C7C.description: Examine and assess the concept of sustainability from many perspectives, and develop an understanding of its implications for the wellbeing of self, others, and the environment.

E06CAA1694C64E31969CD5CDE4F629B0.description: Analyze techniques used by industries (e.g., plastic surgery, weight loss products, diets) and the mass media to influence judgement and values about the way we look.

F18A57E37FE5433298D4436E830E09F9.description: Analyze the relationships between self-esteem and body image.

A379F8D0BB914227B4EE9A8EAA8505A3.description: Understand the pressures/influences that promote unrealistic images of desirable body shape and weight.

182F15E3A00746E1AD2FD1D1E77B417B.description: Explore the different attitudes and behaviours related to self-perception (e.g., body image satisfaction, body image investment, body image behaviour, body image perception) and how difficulties in one or all of these areas creates disturbances in body image

335A8FCB666D4A8A882819A6171E4473.description: Investigate the motivations for and the consequences of being satisfied or dissatisfied with how we look.

DE5491AB9B454411BA2D75A94F1F47A6.description: Discuss body image to include one’s feelings, attitudes, and perceptions towards his/her body and physical appearance.

F0EA27BD3A72462BB2A1E74EF0D17E3D.description: Evaluate personal habits and practices that influence body image satisfaction (e.g., clothing, tanning, piercings).

47BA5578C9F841B38860FC44493E4C56.description: Determine reasons for specific eating and/or exercise habits/ patterns (e.g., time, access, preferences, allergies).

EE8B70E49BFA40CCB238DBCD5C65328C.description: Investigate and evaluate common adolescent and adult eating and exercise habits.

791ABA6AD7B54EAA8F98BE2CA227B8D9.description: Locate and evaluate, according to student-generated criteria, both sources of and information about healthy weights, body image, and self-esteem.

180090AC8CF54CF383A1555B72DCF9C4.description: Assess how body image satisfaction/ dissatisfaction and overreliance on appearance as a source of identity and selfesteem affects the quality of life of self and family.

22B6F902C55143608951E848B5C1443F.description: Investigate sources of help for an abused child, an abused peer, an abused parent/spouse, an abused grandparent/elder, or a family who has a mixture of violent behaviours.

4A3B2DCE3F4F4A519FBF81AB6C4B8470.description: Investigate sources of help for young people who behave in violent ways.

4CBF709AA24342339B747D7AA5BB1EAC.description: Examine historical factors that may contribute to the disharmony within individuals, families, and communities.

739993DE3B2E48E7B16547E35396B9A7.description: Research sources of support for and ways of protecting oneself and others from abuse.

025AD4E3F2ED49D6BD2916FF62ACCEC0.description: Examine threats to personal safety and well-being at home, school, or in the community

CA4924D66B154E47BA51F2AC8B6EC5B6.description: Determine that a victim of violence/abuse is never at fault or to blame for the abuse

81B1949A6D03466ABC1F61D64352EE83.description: Examine why victims of abuse sometimes keep the abuse a secret, and analyze the impact that these “secrets” have on self, family, and community

3D91789B816249179841EF73E86DB501.description: Demonstrate ways to support those who may be experiencing abuse or living with an abusive family member

EBD44AEF862B4658A79C254555779A3F.description: Discuss the factors that are known to contribute to abuse (e.g., stress, exposure to violence, addictions, mental health issues, poverty).

880F9EF060CE4EDCAE894A1CCB7550B8.description: Determine that age does not protect one from abuse (e.g., parental, spousal, child, elder abuse).

B8953F5C095D44A6B3C25F222CD70D9C.description: Assess the impact of physical, emotional, spiritual, and sexual abuse on families and communities.

382FA8FA5C5843DA83568E548181F028.description: Discuss common definitions of “abuse” and “violence” and develop informed personal definitions of both.

40F30DEFF691497DAF7D231D7969DB14.description: Locate and evaluate, according to student-generated criteria, both sources of and information about violence and abuse in families and communities.

B15DF753B21E481E88E47949B7E61301.description: Demonstrate an understanding of the impact of violence (including but not limited to emotional abuse, physical abuse, sexual abuse, spiritual abuse, and neglect) on the well-being of and the supports needed for self, family, and community.

4979C5B47D014023980EF7C2BEB4F7FB.description: Discuss the challenges (e.g., cost of medication, testing ) of curing or treating serious infectious diseases such as Hepatitis C and HIV.

4555566A5DA9434DB44A21B7EC9F96A5.description: Discuss HIV testing as a support service.

2C0A05EF1BAE41A582F1A1375210940F.description: Consider the impact that education has on the kinds of supports available in communities for people infected with/ affected by non-curable infections.

ECDE15C6C9AA4AF595FED340F5E13759.description: Investigate sources of and information about testing for HIV/ AIDS and Hepatitis C.

0BB88A611EAF4CF8AFB542A65AC3FFF2.description: Examine the types of informal and formal community supports available for people infected and/or affected by noncurable and serious but treatable infections/diseases, including HIV/AIDS and Hepatitis C.

63DF0BA9EEE343B7A05C7744635C7D2B.description: Investigate and critique the kinds of supports needed to mitigate some of the behaviours associated with acquiring infectious diseases (e.g., needle exchanges, safer sex practices).

3C7CAAAB09F44C71983B4A6C5DD8C962.description: Describe how misinformation and/or lack of understanding may influence the kinds of supports available to people infected with/affected by non-curable infections.

8373F9A97DFD46D8BEDBE0409E68EDA8.description: Explore the recommended follow-up procedures and supports for those who test positive for the HI virus.

D0F1D96ADFA8403F80139F9C434FE5C0.description: Recognize that some non-curable infections, including HIV, are linked to risky behaviours and not to particular groups of people, and use this knowledge to determine when people should be tested for HIV.

4BEF92F77BD745599AD5E090CF28B268.description: Explore the consequences of having/not having access to treatment options (e.g., cost of medication) and supports (both formal and informal) for self, family, and community

A1A2F568925E40F995FB4418D3AC3FB5.description: Describe the effects of non-curable and serious but treatable infections/diseases, including HIV and Hepatitis on families and communities.

6CC2588F9D044473BFFCB132DBF78B29.description: Locate and evaluate, according to student-generated criteria, both sources of and information about the supports needed/ wanted by individuals, families, and communities infected with/affected by non-curable or serious but treatable infections/diseases (including HIV and Hepatitis C).

83DBE3E2D9D942DA8454CA3AA8754933.description: Investigate and analyze the impact of in/formal supports and services (including testing/ diagnostic services) available to individuals, families, and communities infected with/ affected by non-curable and serious but treatable infections/diseases (including HIV and Hepatitis C).

CA22964613D5482D8787125E6A4D83F1.description: Question examples of injustice towards families in own communities.

BE30881113C34FE6BB2B17E0924D7F34.description: Analyze how stereotyping and social constructions (e.g., gender, “poor bashing”, white privilege) affect the well-being of self, family, and community

F19CA7915308468B9F2552F3D080B896.description: Reflect on personal prejudices and their influences on assumptions about families.

95AC341D2D464CD8B510183F0D2542A8.description: Recognize, name, and challenge instances of inequity, bias, intolerance, and discrimination related to family identities, structures, roles, and responsibilities.

CB7825B210244F8DBEA1311E86E1BCB6.description: Examine how prejudices/biases are learned attitudes and behaviours.

563152395F1D4A2F92C5C07B21D7B812.description: Investigate how the differences that exist in families are respected and protected in Canadian human rights legislation.

242039FCC48D41BC89E89357FE636E34.description: Examine the prejudices/biases that exist in the community.

82108D91DE614D439D211202463C4F14.description: Analyze personal beliefs about family structures, roles, and responsibilities.

5B5E0675E85A439A98C18BEE276CC8A4.description: Explore the expectations that parents/caregivers and children/youth have of one another.

F840B9FD655C4DE4899B79E4C068EABD.description: Examine the family responsibilities associated with family roles.

D53219D047D547BDBC3DBC3582DC0644.description: Analyze gender roles that exist in many families.

9EE7AA9207DB440E963315E95FA990E6.description: Examine family member roles and how they are established.

EFDF8273A6674854868A0A3A7EDA1511.description: Describe a variety of family structures (e.g., nuclear, mixed, childless, foster, same-sex, single parent, extended).

079061D24CFE499CA3DC66257A651DF3.description: Analyze how personal prejudices/biases, and habits of mind shape assumptions about family identities, structures, roles, and responsibilities.

6CA7B2F6AECD487F8880CB3F542156C9.description: Distinguish between help that supports greater independence and that which creates dependence.

5C216D7A01BA4179940772B61D87DEB0.description: Discuss concepts such as learned dependence and empowerment or “helping others to help themselves”

D8725F2772D1466C9977CF7919EE9699.description: Recognize times and situations in which others might appreciate help.

85213C36F34A4FE49653198EF193E610.description: Analyze personal preferences for receiving support.

8522139249ED485190263DBCB1A6B138.description: Assess personal aptitudes for supporting others.

697413596F1F45F0AF09F43442050424.description: Determine the traits and skills of an effective support person.

16750A1861C0443BA996E04FE90A41BB.description: Compare past and present examples (including traditional First Nations and Métis cultures) of how people support/ supported the health of others.

9A8D7AE6F7EB4C4B901BE0CE185371BA.description: Compare informal and formal community supports and how to access them.

E1D70448391B4D3ABD26DA94ECC95EA3.description: Examine the functions of support persons and networks

5BAA85EB10D24A1BB9612F4E50BD1101.description: Describe the benefits one receives from helping others.

70C9FF3BFFA244AE8326DFCB0A0EC55B.description: Locate and evaluate, according to student-generated criteria, both sources of and information about support strategies.

E86A982F30434109828C65C6515B5416.description: Analyze and establish effective strategies of support for purposes of helping others increase health-enhancing behaviours.

4968AE97ABEB4ECE948898BAAF0F13FF.description: Develop the understanding, skills, and confidences necessary to take action to improve health.
